Chronic kidney disease (CKD) can be affected by various dietary components. In the pathogenesis of HRS, there is a complex interplay of factors due to liver dysfunction that affects the kidneys. This includes alterations in the circulation that lead to a reduction in effective blood volume and activation of various systems in an attempt to maintain circulatory function.

Notably in HRS:
- Plasma renin and angiotensin concentrations often increase as a compensatory mechanism because of perceived low effective arterial blood volume.
- Sympathetic nervous system activity increases, also in response to lower effective arterial blood volume, leading to vasoconstriction and an attempt to maintain blood pressure.
- Portal blood flow is reduced due to the cirrhotic process in the liver, contributing to portal hypertension.
- Systemic blood pressure may be reduced due to the overall decreased vascular resistance in the context of end-stage liver disease.
- Plasma vasopressin (antidiuretic hormone) concentrations increase as the body attempts to retain water to counter the effects of reduced blood volume.
